Once the Buddha was wandering in the country of Shravasti, at Jetavana, in Anathapindika's grove, together with a great assembly of monks.
The Buddha told the monks:
Long ago, countless eons ago, there were two siblings.
The older sister had a son, who worked together with his uncle in the imperial weaving workshop, weaving precious and extraordinary garments of gold thread, brocade, silk, and gauze.
Seeing the fine treasures in the treasury, his greedy thoughts stirred, and he discussed it with his uncle, saying:
'We work diligently and tirelessly, and know the good and bad, as well as the quantity of the treasures in the treasury. Wouldn't it be better to take some to relieve our poverty?'
In the middle of the night, when everyone was asleep, they dug a tunnel and stole countless treasures from the imperial treasury.
The next morning, when the treasury was inspected, it was found that treasures were missing, and this was reported to the king.
The king issued a decree, saying:
'Do not spread it widely or let outsiders know.
As for the uncle and nephew thieves, it means that the king is busy with many affairs and cannot be aware of it. By the next day, they will surely be frightened and will come again.
Just strengthen the guards and wait for them. If you catch them, arrest them and do not let them escape.'
The treasury supervisor received the order and immediately increased the guards. After a long time, they came again to steal.
The nephew taught his uncle:
'Uncle, you are old and weak, and if you are caught by the guards, you will not be able to escape.
Go from the ground cave and walk backwards. If they see you, I am strong and will save you.'
As soon as the uncle entered the cave, he was seized by the guards.
The guards called out, and the guards caught the nephew but did not restrain him.
Fearing that they would recognize him the next day, he immediately cut off his uncle's head, left the cave, and took it back.
In the morning, the treasury supervisor reported it in detail.
The king again ordered:
'Carry out the corpse and place it at a crossroads. Whoever cries out and takes the dead body is the leader of the thieves.'
They abandoned it at a crossroads, and the guards kept watch for many days.

At that time, a great merchant came from a distant land. People, horses, and carts filled the roads, rushing and crowding. The man was noisy, carrying two carts of firewood and placing the corpse on top.
The guards reported this in detail to the king the next morning, and the king ordered them to secretly observe:
'If the observation is not thorough and someone burns it, arrest and bind them and bring them here.'
Then the nephew, leading a servant, held up a torch and danced playfully. The crowd was noisy, and they threw fire onto the firewood, which burned fiercely.
The guards did not notice and reported this in detail to the king.
The king again ordered:
'If it has already been burned, increase the guards and strictly watch for anyone who comes to take the bones. They will be the leader.'
The nephew also woke up and, together with the wine, specially made it very strong and went to the guards, secretly selling it to them.
The guards, having been hungry and thirsty for a long time, saw the wine and drank it together with Zong, drinking too much and all falling into a drunken sleep.
They captured the wine jar and took the bones away, the guards not noticing. The next day, they again reported to the king.
The king again decreed:
The guards have not captured the bandit, who is cunning and crafty. We must devise a plan.
The king then sent out his daughter, adorned with jeweled necklaces and precious ornaments, and set up a room by the great waters.
The people guarded her, watching for any falsehood, and if there was a man of good color who approached the woman,
they had previously instructed the woman not to resist embracing him, but to call out for the people to capture him.
On another night, the nephew secretly came and released the log downstream along the water, shouting and running quickly. The guards were startled and rushed to the scene, thinking:
'There is a strange person!'
But only seeing stumps and stumps, in this way, connected with the past, repeatedly unchanged, the guard cherished and practiced, sleeping without alarm.
The nephew then rode on the stump and arrived at the woman's room. The woman then grabbed his clothes. The nephew said to the woman:
'Why do you pull on my clothes? You can grab my arm instead.'
The nephew was originally a doctor, and he had already prepared a dead person's arm to give to the woman. The woman then let go of his clothes and turned to grab the dead arm, crying out loudly.
The guard woke up, and the nephew was able to escape.
The next day, he fully reported to the king. The king again decreed:
'This person's skillful means is unique and unmatched. For a long time, he has not been caught. What should be done?'
The woman then became pregnant and gave birth to a son after ten months.
When the son grew up, he was handsome. He had a wet nurse carry him around the country, saying:
'If anyone sees him and wants to kiss him, they should be bound and brought here.'
The wet nurse carried the child all day, but no one wanted to kiss him.

The nephew was a baker, living under a bakery. The child was hungry and crying. The wet nurse held the child and went to the bakery to buy some bread to feed the child. When the nephew saw the child, he gave it some bread and made a sound.
The wet nurse returned and reported to the king, saying:
The child has been out all day and no one has come near it. When it was hungry and passed by the bakery, the baker gave it bread and made a sound.
The king again ordered:
Why didn't you capture and send it?
The wet nurse replied:
